title: MV Gurusamy, Pandit Ramalingam and S Gopalakrishnan with daughter Selvi singing at the Tank Road Temple

 Pandit Ramalingam and S Gopalakrishnan with daughter Selvi singing at the Tank Road Temple

  physical_appearance: The image shows a rectangular photograph that is in black-and-white. The photograph features three males and a young girl
 sitting on a raised platform. There is a microphone stand near to the young girl
 who appears to be singing. One man is playing a harmonium while the other is using a violin. A crowd of people watching them can be seen in the background of the photograph. The background of the photograph suggests that this was taken in the interior of a building.

  subject_terms_1: temples (buidings) singers musical performances musicians children (people by age group) music (performing arts)

  subject_terms_2: Carnatic music Tamil (Indic people) Hindu temples Singers Musicians Children and adults Performances Black-and-white photography

  subject_terms_3: Temples Performing Arts Photography Indian music Sri Thendayuthapani Temple Musicians

  sgcool_label_text: Mr. S Gopalakrishnan (b. in 1920 in Tanjavur) was a prominent violinist
 and Carnatic singer. He arrived in Singapore in 1939 and actively participated in the Indian classical music scene here. Mr Gopalakrishnan performed alongside veterans of classical performers such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy at temple and other music festivals. He also taught violin lessons at the Singapore Malayalee Association from the 1970s to 2000s. He was a member of the Tamils Reform Association and performed his wedding according to the principles of the Self-Respect Movement. He was also employed as a compositor at the Far East Air Force from 1954 to 1970.

He arrived in Singapore in 1939 and actively participated in the Indian classical music scene here. Mr Gopalakrishnan performed alongside veterans of classical performers such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy at temple and other music festivals. He also taught violin lessons at the Singapore Malayalee Association from the 1970s to 2000s. He was a member of the Tamils Reform Association and performed his wedding according to the principles of the Self-Respect Movement. He was also employed as a compositor at the Far East Air Force from 1954 to 1970.
